Other countries have been able to provide Government papers on it, and although I realise that the negotiations which leave us in the present situation are not much older than a week, it would have been possible to have provided the guts of a White Paper by now, to have put in print reasonable tables and details. I had nearly exhausted my stock of condemnations when the Green Paper came out, but the Green Paper was an Encyclopaedia Britannica compared with this. Apart from its pitiable external appearance, apart from the fact that one would be ashamed to let a foreigner get the impression that this is what we mean by a White Paper, I have to say that there is almost nothing in it which might not have been supplied from the debate here last October.

Speaker.P: Let me point out that I said in this House at the conclusion of the debate in October that if the other side insisted on a paper by a particular date they would get a paper but the content would depend on what could be produced at that time. I had to hand out the prospect of postponing the date of the debate until we could have sufficient material and I was denounced from those benches. The suggestion was immediately made that we were trying to go back on commitments, to which I promptly replied that if the Opposition wanted a debate on any particular day they could have it.
Deputy Kelly may welcome interruptions, the Minister may welcome them but the Chair does not stand for this at all. Deputy Kelly invited interruptions.
If the Minister wishes to interrupt he is welcome to do so. I yield to him with pleasure. I do not get apoplexy when interrupted.
The Chair does not want interruptions. They are not in order.

I can remember the Minister saying something along the lines he has now outlined, but let us take what Deputy O'Leary and others have been saying about their worries on the EMS question, and that is the immediate impact that joining the EMS without Britain will have on certain vulnerable industrial sectors. Either the Department of Economic Planning and Development, if they are worth their salt, have information and have made assessments in regard to these vulnerable sectors or they have not that information and have not made those assessments? If they have not the information and have not made the assessments, then the Minister should resign and take his Department with him. If they have the information and have made those assessments and have anything to say to industry or the unions, why can it not be said here in the White Paper? Although this bundle of typescript weighs a couple of ounces, it consists mostly of photocopies of EEC documentation. I have seen more trouble put into a script for the Minister for Health in opening a swimming pool or the Minister for the Environment in opening a car salesroom. It is beyond belief, even with all the reservations made by the Minister opposite, that the Government could seriously produce this as a document on which this House might discuss this historic step. It is a feeble effort. The speech with which the Minister opened the debate this morning was also a feeble effort and he almost forgot to mention the White Paper.

MainHeading.P: I am in doubt—and I am sure the Minister would admit the same—as to what I would do if there were a lever or switch in front of me, the operation of which would put us into the EMS. I can see there are arguments in both directions and I recognise the force of them. I agree with the Minister and I believe I would carry my party with me in saying we are in favour of the EMS if the conditions are right. I understood that to be the position of the Labour Party also. The Minister said the same thing on 16 October. He said we would go in if the conditions were right. What does that tell us? We would go to live in the Arctic circle if the conditions were right and we could make the place habitable. The Minister has not told us what the conditions are. He has not related the conditions on which he has been insisting abroad to deal with problems which will clearly arise here in the event of the entry of this country to the EMS while Britain remains outside.

In October I tried to warn the Government against giving in to what I then described as a “weak-witted Wolfe Toneism” according to which there was some inherent benefit in breaking the link with this or throwing off the fetters of that when the possibility is, whatever the historical reasons which make us to some extent dependent on the market. next door, that by striking that kind of bold attitude thousands could be put out of work. I completely reject that kind of emotion as being a worthy component in a debate of this kind. I would not give a thraneen for the emotional difficulty talked about by some inside the House and commentators outside the House of finding ourselves isolated in a situation where we may be accused of trailing along on Britain's coat tails if the Italians join the system. Of course I feel it in the sense that I have a lot of “little boy” feelings of one kind or another about railway trains or bright uniforms and brass bands, but it is not worth a thraneen to the people who will be thrown out of work if we make the wrong decision on the head of an emotional response of that kind. The Minister knows that. The trouble with the Minister is that through a concatenation of personal circumstances, perhaps even accidents which he may now regret, he has joined a party in which it is poison to speak the truth about matters like that or to qualify the Green Flag in the slightest particular at any time or for any reason.

I am in favour of the EMS if it will reduce the fluctuation of exchange rates and bring our inflation down to the level of the strongest economies in Europe. Nobody on these benches has said a word against that. Of course we are in favour of it. I looked at the situation as presented by the Taoiseach, the Tánaiste and the Minister opposite in October last and I asked what the major snag would be if we were to enter the system while the British remained outside. I want to emphasise once again that I do not give a thraneen about the British one way or the other. Let them paddle their own canoe. I feel no sense of responsibility, allegiance or alliance with them, though no doubt it will suit the lower echelons of the Minister's party to allege otherwise. They can paddle their own canoe; they have their own resources and their own advice and apart from the general solidarity which one is expected to show to another member state of the EEC I have absolutely no further feeling about them whatsoever.

The plain fact is that we import relatively far more from Britain than from any other trading partner. The most recent figures I could find show that in the months January to August of this year the proportion of goods imported from Britain has actually risen compared with last year. The figure is about 49 per cent in the first eight months of this year as against 47 per cent in the same period last year. I agree that the difference is marginal but the point remains valid. We import a very heavy percentage of goods from Britain and those goods are in competition on the home market with Irish goods, while our exports are in competition with the same goods on the British market. Any Government who do not spell out these things in terms which a simple soul can understand are not doing their job properly.

My party have not infiltrated the Confederation of Irish Industry. I have no idea of the politics of most of their members, though some of them make no secret of their politics. I have no inside information about the allegiance of the confederation. They are all businessmen and I do not believe one of them would support a political party which he regarded as hostile to his own business interests. Early this year the CII computed that the existence of the British temporary employment subsidy had cost in the textile and footwear industries alone about 3,500 jobs. I did not put those words into their mouths. They calculated that because the British competitive position had been permitted to be distorted by the provision of a temporary employment subsidy, 3,500 Irish men and women were out of jobs which they otherwise would have held. That subsidy was a serious matter and I pursued it on many occasions in the House. On one such occasion I managed to discover that the first time an official protest was made to Brussels about that subsidy was, by a funny coincidence, the day I put down a question in the House asking the Minister when such a protest had first been made. That was I February.

Leaving aside the question of where blame lies for the neglect of the Government in regard to the British temporary employment subsidy, I should like to know why the White Paper does not set out some kind of assessment of a difference in value of 1 per cent, 2 per cent, 5 per cent or even up to the supposed limit of 6 per cent between our currency and the currency next door if, because of being shackled to continental currencies, our currency drifts or is pulled upwards vis-à-vis the British currency. I realise that not many Deputies have mentioned the White Paper for reasons I have tried to explain. Has the Minister made any calculation as to the effects of a difference of that order in the prices of Irish goods in ranges in which Irish goods compete with British goods?

I want to mention a matter which I hope will not be thought contemptible because a lot of time is devoted to it in other contexts. Has the Minister computed the effect on tourism if the Irish £ were to drift up substantially as against the British £? That is not an argument against joining the EMS by ourselves but it is a consideration I would have expected to be spelled out by a Government who were doing their job and purporting to put out a White Paper instead of this schoolboy's blotter. We depend on tourism to an enormous extent to close our trade gap as the Minister knows and if he does not know it he should not be in his job. What effect will it have on hotel prices if the Irish £ is worth more than the English £ to the extent that Irish holidays will be that much less competitive? Why has that not been mentioned? Why have the tens of millions of pounds that we get out of tourism each year not been taken into this computation and if they have been taken into account why have we not been told about them?

That brings me to the question about the progress of these negotiations and the kind of result obtained by the Government. What were we told in the communiqué that emerged after the summit on 5 December? It is set out in 3.4 of the White Paper:

The funds thus provided are to be concentrated on the financing of selected infrastructure projects and programmes, with the understanding that any direct or indirect distortion of the competitive position of specific industries within member States will have to be avoided.

Why is there that understanding? It was put into the communiqué as if it was something as unalterable as the laws of the Medes and the persians or as the sun rises in the morning and sinks in the evening. In his speech this morning when the Taoiseach was taking to task one of the leaders of the Opposition parties—I have forgotten which one—he adverted to this matter. He said, “surely you did not expect me to look for protection or shelter for industry when the whole point of the EEC is to do away with that?”

The only achievement the White Paper considered worth mentioning was that it was on the Taoiseach's suggestion that the communique of 6-7 July contained a reference to the “need for concurrent studies of the measures to be taken to strengthen the economies of the less prosperous member states and the fact that such measures were essential for the success of the system.” That was included on the Taoiseach's proposal and I am grateful to him for making sure it was done. However, when it gets down to the things that obviously will be matters of difficulty here what do we get? In July the Taoiseach said that he struck this blow for Ireland, that he ensured the communiqué included a paragraph about strengthening the weaker economies but in December we get a paragraph that not only does not envisage some help for the sector where help will be needed but which specifically rules it out.

I cannot see what is so non-negotiable about assistance for an industry that suddenly finds itself threatened by a development of this kind. I do not think I am quite in the dark about what the EEC is about. When we joined the EEC on 1 January 1973 we were not thrown in at the deep end immediately. Transitional measures were applied to ease the shock, and this was quite right. I should like the Minister in his reply to tell us if there is not some analogy between the shock of joining the EEC in the first place and of finding ourselves part of the proposed monetary system now. Surely there is something comparable in the shock to be experienced by the threatened sectors and tourism, which has not been mentioned, with the shock a large part of industry experienced on 1 January 1973? Why is it so unthinkable that there should be some special measures to protect the threatened sectors of Irish industry during some transitional period whose duration geniuses in the Minister's Department could work out? I could not say whether six months, one year or two years would be necessary but I take it the Minister has an opinion on how long, in the event of a relative devaluation of the British £, Irish industry would have to adjust itself in order to compete on level terms? Why is that so automatically excluded?

In common with many other Deputies I have to learn much of this stuff as I go along but I cannot help looking at the gaping hole in the Government's negotiating record and what they were looking for. The Government were looking for a figure of about £650 million spread over five years. In October last the Minister for Economic Planning and Development when asked by Deputy O'Leary if the Government were looking for loans or grants replied “grants”. Even the founder of his party would have found it difficult to take out of that reply any meaning other than grants mean grants. That is what the Minister was looking for. Even if he got that and not merely soft loans, what would the grants have amounted to? I know that simple people—I would not be offended at being included in that category when considering this matter—are baffled by large sums of money that are many thousands of times more than they will have occasion to spend and over which they will never have disposal powers. What is £650 million spread over five years? I do not know if the Minister has looked at it this way. Even if we had got that amount it would have to be devoted to infrastructural projects but it is not much more than the State, substantially out of its own resources, has spent on telephones in the past few years and we have a long way to go there. We could sink £650 million in the telephone system and not see it.

I represent a constituency in which there has been quite understandable resentment because of a promise to which no less a personage than the Taoiseach himself added his authority three days before the election. Senator Ryan had the authority of Deputy Lynch to give his personal commitment to the building of a new dual carriageway that would take the strain off a series of completely inadequate narrow suburban roads leading roughly from Palmerstown or Chapelizod to the Dún Laoghaire car ferry. The difference between the Minister's party and mine is that we made no rash promises about it. We could have lashed out 50,000 circulars saying that Liam Cosgrave would provide that road but we did not do so.

Speaker.P: They would not believe the Deputy's party.

They will not believe Fianna Fáil next time. It did not stop the election centre which had one overriding instruction for the campaign, namely, that no local or community demand, however unreasonable or reckless, was to be refused and that even things that had not been looked for, such as the remission of car tax, were to be promised.
We are discussing the motion.

I shall stick to the Southern Cross road route. I do not know if the traffic on that road thunders past the Minister's door but it could not be too far away. When Deputy Niall Andrews was beating a retreat from the commitment from which he benefited I think I heard him put a figure of £70-£80 million on it. That is a small section of dual carriageway that one could lose on the map of Dublin. How far would £650 million go in building roads, in supplying telephones? Would it compensate for the destruction of a substantial part of the traditional industry that is labour intensive?

CIE are getting up on their hind legs at last and are demanding what they should have demanded a long time ago, and they are not making any secret of the problems. They are expected to run a bus service in a city which is choked with tax free cars—an extra 100,000 of them have joined the road since this Government came in. They are also expected to run a rail service which is bulging at the seams in the dirtiest, most dilapidated coaches this side of Baghdad. This cannot go on. Day in and day out the commuter trains from Dundalk in one direction and from Bray in the other break down and leave as many people stranded on the line as would a bomb scare. CIE say that they have to have a new electrified commuter service on the Dublin suburban lines and that they have to have new rolling stock. All one has to do to see the need for all this is to buy a 25p ticket and travel from Westland Row to Dún Laoghaire.

MainHeading.P: How much will all that cost? Would there be an awful lot of change from the £650 million, even if the Government got it, which they will not? I cannot understand why these points have not been taken up with a bit more emphasis before this. I know that is a lot of money, but devoted to infrastructure and not devoted to things which really need money, it is a drop in the bucket compared to what we need. If the EMS were never heard of we would still have to find the money for that infrastructure. Suppose the EMS disappeared in smoke tomorrow morning for some reason as little foreseen as was last week's fiasco, are we still not going to have to do something about the Dublin commuter lines? Are we still not going to have to build a Southern Cross Route and provide the infrastructural services that the Confederation of Irish Industry never tires of listing along with bad industrial relations as the chief obstacle to industrial development and prosperity.

I do not wish to be personally offensive, but I wonder if the Taoiseach and the two Ministers opposite are out of their depth with the people they are dealing with in Europe. Are they serious at all? The one thing that people here are afraid of in regard to EMS is loss of industrial employment in the short-term. I am in favour of EMS if we can get the right terms.

Speaker.P: Can the Deputy tell us who would be in his depth if we are all out of our depth and he has admitted that he is not an expert? Can the Deputy nominate somebody?
I do not mind having a go.
Good man.

I do not mind having a go if I can get the consent of the people to my changing places with the Minister. I am absolutely certain that I would not go to Europe, knowing that I was risking 10,000 industrial jobs, and look for an amount of money that would barely build 15 miles of motorway around the four or five biggest towns. I would be afraid of making a laughing stock of myself. I would not do anything for a sum of money that would not electrify the Dublin commuter rail service and provide it with proper rolling stock.

MainHeading.P: That team of Ministers might have made a special case and might have made some effort to bring home the special situation of this country in regard to EMS membership. They could have emphasised to the Europeans the very special position we have in regard to unemployment. We are at the head of the European league in relation to unemployment. We are in a special position politically, and not just economically, in regard to unemployment. The Minister knows that. The scales of the countries are so different that an increase of 10,000 industrial workers out of their jobs here will have a political impact here. I am not talking about Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael politics. I am talking about the roof over this Parliament. The political impact here will be absolutely out of proportion to a similar loss of jobs among the larger European countries. If you could attract something the size of the Volkswagen works in Wolfsburg, that would on paper solve our entire unemployment problem; but we are on a different scale. An extra 10,000 jobless here is a very serious matter. It is a far more serious matter perhaps even than an extra 100,000 jobless in France or Germany, bearing in mind that the supporters in those countries for the unemployed are a great deal more generous than they are here. Surely, that might have been a reason for asking that we be not pinned to the business of aids, whether loans or grants, not being useable for the purpose of distorting competition. We must distort competition for a few years if we are to join this system. Why was that not said? If it was said why was it not in the White Paper and why was the Taoiseach not only silent about it this morning, but dismissive of such a possibility?

If the Taoiseach or the Ministers opposite are being hard nosed in these negotiations it is not coming through in translation. Possibly, the kind of language that we hear from Deputy Colley comes through a bit more politely in French, German or in Italian. Possibly, the evasions that we hear from the other Minister opposite come through in a different form when mediated by the interpreters in Luxembourg, Brussels, Rome or Bremen. I do not know what the reason is, but it is certain that this Government have not pursued those negotiations on the point I am talking about with sufficiently hard nose. Now we are in the situation where we will find ourselves possibly having to make a very hard decision. I hope it will be properly made, but I will not promise not to say “I told you so” if it is wrong. I am only flesh and blood the same as the rest of us.

Speaker.P: Whatever it is, the Deputy will say it is wrong.

I have nearly given up saying friendly things about Fianna Fáil because as sure as I do someone like Deputy David Andrews will say that I am condescending or being patronising. That is the kind of response I get. Fianna Fáil are so used to dealing with people who can only think in terms of saying whatever offensive thing comes into their heads, even if it is a lie, that they cannot appreciate when somebody says that they agree that Fianna Fáil have made a good job of this or that. This is not, however, one of these instances.
Is the Deputy contemplating the possibility of saying that we are making a good job of it?
Not in this instance.
That is what I said, whatever we do is wrong.

We tried to thrash out the situation in regard to unemployment today, but unfortunately, the Ceann Comhairle would not allow me to pursue the matter. The Minister for Economic Planning and Development said—and this is highly relevant to our EMS situation—that he thought a question which I had put down to extract the ratio between the wealth-producing jobs the Government would claim to have created and those which were not wealth producing was a meaningless question. Would the Minister say that to Mr. Schmidt, to Mr. Giscard, or to even the humblest functionary from the remotest village in Apulia or Jutland and expect to be taken seriously? The Minister would not: he would be ashamed to say such a thing. What the Minister said today amounted to saying that if the female half of our population were all nurses and the male half were all gardaí, we could have the very same standard of living we have now. We could not and the Minister knows it.
I did not say that.

The Minister knows that there is a distinction between a job which creates wealth and a job which simply consumes it. I did not say those jobs were not productive. They are productive, because they produce a service which we must have; but they are not wealth productive. Any Government can borrow enough money, can buy enough desks and chairs and put enough people behind them with enough typewriters. We could have done that if we had no sense of responsibility. I am still waiting for an answer to that question. I regard the Minister as being guilty of a gross evasion by the line he took here today about it. I cannot believe that the Minister would stand over an answer of that kind if he were dealing with the people in Europe.

We are being brought now to the brink of an historic decision, which will be made the right way, I hope, for the sake of all of us, and to the brink of a situation in which the Irish £ will be judged by itself for the first time ever. It is such a small appendage at the moment to the currency area represented by these islands that nobody has ever asked what the Irish £ is worth alone. That question will be asked when we first enter this system. I presume there will be an initial value at which we enter the system for the Irish £. We are in a weak position. I am not selling us short. I read the Minister's speech in October where he mentioned a couple of the favourable factors in regard to the inherent value of the Irish currency but left out the weak factors. The weak factors are that our wages policy, if it can be called that, is in an indescribable state of chaos.

MainHeading.P: Wage demands of a level previously unheard of are being made. The Minister knows this and he complains about it himself although his party created the atmosphere which made it certain that these demands would be made, in which the guards are looking for 40 per cent, the nurses for 50 per cent, higher civil servants for a rise of £88 per week, not just £88 per week. Would the Minister dare to ask for a rise like that? Of course they are only the asking prices but did the Minister show these figures to Helmut Schmidt or to Giscard D'Estaing? I am damn sure he did not. Did he show them the trade figures which we have had for three months in succession, a record trade deficit for three months?

All these features are the negative side of our situation but the hard-headed people of the kind that the Taoiseach and his Ministers find themselves out of their depth with are able to do their sums. I am sure they are in possession of the official figures which reflect these things. They have embassies here with very little else to do except make newspaper cuttings, with very little else to do except sniff out reports of wage demands here of temporising there and of commissions being set up on conditions of pay and so on. They are able to draw their conclusions about what a spineless Government we have, a Government which reached power after an election the like of which would not be seen anywhere else in Europe. If the Fianna Fáil manifesto had been produced in the remotest hamlet of western Europe they would have been laughed out of it. If the country is facing difficulties, I do not want the Taoiseach and his Ministers looking down their noses making solemn faces at me and asking me to show restraint. What restraint did they show when they were out chasing votes?

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Economic Planning and Development (Professor O'Donoghue) Martin O'Donoghue
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Economic Planning and Development (Professor O'Donoghue)
Speaker.P: I should like to be able to reply to the many points that have been raised and the many hares that have been flushed out in the course of the debate. Alas, time prevents me from doing so but I cannot resist dealing with a few of them, even the ones that are extraneous to the issues before us.

MainHeading.P: While it is fresh in my mind I will deal with Deputy Kelly's remarks about wealth-producing employment, saying how wrong I was to imply that the jobs could not be classified into wealth-producing and non-wealth-producing employment. He suggested that I was trying to say that if all the men were engaged as police and all the women were engaged as nurses we could still enjoy the same standard of living. Of course I did not suggest it. Neither did I suggest that if we had no nurses and if we had no policemen and if everybody was engaged in what the Deputy would presumably describe as wealth-producing employment, making ticky-tacky boxes in ticky-tacky factories——

Speaker.P: Is the Minister contemptuous of box factories?

No, I am not but this is the example the Deputy quoted to me today. I am simply making the point that one cannot describe or define wealth-producing employment in simplified terms. There is ultimately involved what I might describe as a fallacy of composition. That is why I refused to answer the question but I invited the Deputy to submit his description of what he regarded as wealth-producing and non-wealth-producing occupations. I will supply the numbers corresponding to those and the Deputy can make what use he thinks appropriate of them, but the Deputy was not going to have me supplying allegedly wealth-producing or non-wealth-producing classifications. That is the point I am making.
Does the Minister not recognise any distinction even remotely like the one I am trying to make.

No. The question was tabled to me. The Minister accepts responsibility for the replies. I am telling the Deputy the reasons why I refused to answer in the terms I was invited to. I am also saying why I disagree with the references which he made and why I think he is wrong, but I am open to persuasion in the matter.

MainHeading.P: The closing theme of his address, “no matter what we get it is not enough”, helps me to lead into a discussion of the issues before us. There ought to have been two separate themes. One was the question of the EMS and the issues surrounding the nature of that system and the extent to which Ireland would benefit from membership of it. That was the substantive issue for debate. Tacked onto it there was a separate issue concerning the negotiations leading up to the Brussels Summit of last week and on the various discussions which took place afterwards. First of all, we had the play itself, the EMS, and then we had discussions about the players. The bulk of the contributions from the other side of the House, crudely summarised, seemed to suggest that they did not think much of the system because they did not think much of the players. They tried to convey the notion that the proposals which emerged from the Summit were clearly inadequate because of the inadequacy of the Taoiseach and his Ministers in the preparations which led up to the proposals issuing from that Summit.

I have to remind Deputy Kelly that judged simply on the criterion of the amount of money that was put forward as a suggestion, £45 million in terms of grants, represents a substantially larger sum than the amounts which were forthcoming from regional funds negotiated by the Coalition Government. Therefore, if we were inadequate then the other side of the House must be grossly inadequate by some factor of five, six or perhaps even tenfold.

The Deputy is also pursuing the notion that not alone would it be inadequate because it was not up to the amount originally sought but that the amount sought was itself inadequate. I recall hearing that one from Deputy FitzGerald who misleadingly introduced estimates associated with my name, estimates produced in a different context for a different purpose.

The proposals put forward by this Government in the context of the EMS are not to be confused, should not be confused, and have only been confused by the leader of Fine Gael and some of his acolytes as being appropriate in the EMS context. That inability to distinguish between the characteristics of the EMS and the characteristics of a full European economic and monetary union is symptomatic of the confusion which has characterised that side of the House, especially many of the utterances of Deputy FitzGerald. I shall return to that subject because I want to emphasise that the confusion is not on this side of the House.

Because of the many references to the personnel involved in the negotiations, including myself, I trust I will be forgiven if I take time to deal with some of these remarks as they affect me. The Tánaiste said today that the nature of the statements made in the House last week precluded any effective reply from us. I was accused by Deputy FitzGerald of making statements on RTE radio last week which were at variance with what the Taoiseach had said. Some people in the media even went so far as to dramatise the nature of that alleged difference and the motivation for it. What I was saying was not at variance in any way that I could identify with what the Taoiseach was saying. Let me quote from a transcript which I have been given. I went on to state the various terms. Then I was asked did the package fall short of what the Government had sought and I said yes, it did. Then I said on the basis of the proposals that had been put forward, the Taoiseach had said that he could not say that he would recommend it at this time: “That is why no formal decision was taken and the Taoiseach indicated that he would want the Government to discuss it and that he would want the opportunity of examining some of the possibilities further before any final decision is taken. That decision should emerge within the next week or two”. That was my attempt in my words to repeat what the Taoiseach had said the night before where, although he had indicated that the package as offered was not one that he felt he could recommend, he went on to say that nonetheless he would seek to explore other possibilities.

Speaker.P: May I ask who gave the Minister the transcript of the RTE interview?
Somebody put on a cassette tape recorder as it was being broadcast and had it typed for me.
It does not matter; carry on, that is just a silly interruption.
I was given it.
That is not what the Minister said.

Pardon my ignorance then if I used the word transcript misleadingly; somebody took a recording of what I said on RTE; somebody typed that recording for me and somebody gave me a copy of it—is that all right? I hope I am repeating verbatim what I said on that occasion. I have indicated that, in my words, I was attempting to repeat what the Taoiseach had said the night before. At the end I was again asked my own personal views and I said it would be premature at this stage: “I am not offering any views. I said it would be premature at this stage to try to say whether we are in or out”. That is all I said in that whole context —no final decision was taken; it would be premature at this stage to try to say whether we were in or out.

Some people for their own purposes—I do not know their motivation—were quite willing to seek to impute a motivation to me and the one thing I want to have is the opportunity of putting on the records of this House that in making those statements the furthest thought from my mind was in any way to appear to be at variance with what the Taoiseach had said or in any way to undermine or weaken his decision, that I went out——
We will buy that.
Let us have the laughter then. By his laughter the Deputy is implying that what I am saying is untrue? He has a remarkable capacity for trying to impute dishonesty or inaccuracy to what I say.
I accept totally the Minister's subservient position.

Thank you very much. I gladly acknowledge that it is a subservient position. I fully recognise the leadership of my Taoiseach which is more than I can say for the position of many of the people on those benches when Deputy Cosgrave was Taoiseach.
He who excuses himself very often accuses himself.
More of the Bible.

I have made my statement. It is the first opportunity I have had of making the statement in this House and I want to do it as fully and freely and as accurately as I can. I hope that will be an end of the matter. I think that is all I need say on that point.

MainHeading.P: A number of points were raised in the debate this morning. I shall try to deal with them quickly. Again, there was this notion of seeking to impute confusion or contradiction to this side of the House with Deputy Cluskey at one stage saying that there was a contradiction between the White Paper which referred to a detailed review as the basis for our assessment for these resource transfers and a paragraph in the Taoiseach's speech where the Taoiseach had said that there were far too many variables involved for anyone to be able to conclude that any sector would, of necessity—my emphasis—be adversely affected by our entry into the new system. There is no contradiction there whatever because the basis for seeking resource transfers was geared to a likely programme of expenditure which would be undertaken to strengthen our infrastructure, to improve investment in our industry. That is one type of calculation which can be made and which was made as the basis for our case. It is quite a separate calculation to seek to identify what would happen to each individual industry or sector of the economy in the event of our membership because one would have to specify the particular characteristics that one envisages for membership—and there are quite a number of possible circumstances. If I had time, I would develop that point but I simply make the essential point that there is no contradiction between what was said in the White Paper and what was contained in the Taoiseach's remarks in the House this morning.

Deputy Cluskey also said incidentally that there was no resource transfer involved in these loans, these soft loans that had been offered. I shall be coming back to that. I just want to note it carefully. There is a transfer involved and I shall refer to its value in a few minutes.

Speaker.P: From us to them.

Deputy FitzGerald made a number of points quite a few of which were dealt with by the Tánaiste in his remarks earlier today, so I can take them as dealt with. One point which Deputy FitzGerald stressed a few times was the emphasis on the manner in which a special line had been introduced into the regional fund to provide an extra six million units of account for Ireland several years ago. He asked why did we not seek to have recourse to this type of approach when we were presenting our case. The fact is that we not only looked at that possibility but at a number of others also. To update the position, may I point out here that arrangements for regional policy, the regional fund and so on have moved on quite a bit since then and that there is also a non-quota section of the fund at the present time and that this could also be an appropriate vehicle.

Another point raised by Deputy FitzGerald was that 9 per cent interest on these loans would be excessive. But, of course, no one has ever suggested what the actual rate of interest on any such EEC loans would be. The 9 per cent rate referred to on a number of occasions on this side of the House related to the interest rate that was used in order to arrive at the value of the subsidy contained in these loans. It is a number used in order to carry out a calculation. This is where I can come I think to something that I was invited to do last week by Deputy FitzGerald. I am sorry he is not here to hear it.
I think Deputy FitzGerald would wish the Minister to realise that no discourtesy to the Minister is intended.

I see. I trust that in due course he will have an opportunity of consulting the records of the House. So, I shall try to put it on record as carefully as I can. First, he was saying that again one of the points that led to confusion was that in my remarks on RTE radio I had drawn attention to the fact that there was this subsidy element in loans, that there was a five-year moratorium and that there was a value in this moratorium on which a figure had not yet been placed. He thought this contradicted the statement by the Taoiseach where the £45 million calculation did include a moratorium element. A few paragraphs later Dr. FitzGerald said and I quote:

The Taoiseach went on to make the following statement which I am sure is not totally clear to everybody in this House “that the present value of a 3 per cent interest subsidy with a three-year moratorium on capital repayments included in most of the calculations is equivalent to approximately 20 per cent of the value of the loan discounted at 9 per cent. Now, hands up those who understand that, hands up. Does anybody understand it?”

He invited me to put up my hand and it was at that point that I promised him that I would deal with that aspect fully and fairly this evening. I now propose to do so because I want to use this in order to show that the Taoiseach's statement was correct and also to show that there was no difference in that statement of the Taoiseach and my remarks. So, the confusion then is on Deputy FitzGerald's part, not on my part. I might add that since he indicated five unnamed experts in support of his views, I felt that they might carry some weight and that is why I need to refute them as fully, fairly and accurately as I can.

MainHeading.P: Let us set out the basis clearly: we are going to be talking about loans for 15-year periods. Basically there are two ways in which loans can be repaid, if we are thinking of normal commercial situations to begin with. One is by what is called the annuity method, which is the method used with mortgages on houses and so on, where one pays a large amount of interest on the bulk of the loan in the first year and a small amount of capital and then that small amount of capital repayment in the first year, because it can be invested at a rate of interest, will accumulate up to a bigger figure at the end of 15 years and so on; in the second year one pays a smaller amount of interest and a slightly larger amount of capital and that larger amount is now invested for 14 years and so on. That is the annuity method. It is a fairly complex one but there are well-recognised mathematical rules for arriving at the amounts involved.

However, since Deputy FitzGerald specifically asked us to avoid the algebra and to put it into the form of simple arithmetic I am going to use a second method which is simpler, and the degree of error involved is very small; all the approximations will be right to the nearest round numbers. The second method, then, is to simply assume that the capital sum is repaid over the 15 years. The first case we will take is where it is repaid in 15 equal instalments. So we have a loan which is repayable in 15 equal instalments and the first case is where there is no inflation. I emphasise the words “no inflation”. In those circumstances if we consider an ordinary commercial loan at a commercial rate of interest with no inflation and ask if a moratorium has any value in those circumstances the answer is no. That is the one case in which Deputy FitzGerald's five experts might have been right. If that was the question he put to them then their answer is one with which I would agree. But I doubt if that was the question that was put, for reasons I will come to.

I now wish to move on to pick up the value of an interest subsidy, because we were asked to explain it. If calculating the value of a subsidy I need a more convenient way, using simple arithmetic, to illustrate how long one borrows money for if one repays in 15 equal instalments over a 15-year period. That is equivalent to saying that one borrows the whole sum for the whole of eight years and then repays it in one lump sum. So instead of borrowing £100 and repaying it by 15 instalments of something under £7 a year for each of the 15 years one would incur the same amount of interest if one borrowed £100 and paid interest only for eight years and then repaid the loan at that point. That is equivalent to an eight-year full term loan. So an ordinary 15-year loan with no moratorium is equivalent to a full term loan of eight years.

If we now introduce a moratorium it has the effect of postponing the average date at which one makes the capital repayment. If it is a five-year moratorium that means one makes no capital repayments in each of the first five years but one must now make larger capital repayments from the sixth to the fifteenth year. The combined effect of those two elements is that on average one borrows the money for ten-and-a-half-years instead of eight years so the effect of the five-year moratorium is to postpone the average date of repayment by two-and-a-half-years, from eight years to ten-and-a-half-years.

Now we can introduce the value of the interest subsidy plus the value of the moratorium: If we take the simple case of 2 per cent interest subsidy on a loan of £100 million then the subsidy would be £2 million in the first year, £1.1 million in the eighth year and it would be down to £130,000 in the last year and so on. But if my simple rule is applied and we just say it is equivalent to a full eight-year loan then one would just take £2 million for eight years, £16 millions, as the amount of cash that would be associated with the subsidy over this full eight years. But what is the value of £16 million spread over an eight-year period? To answer that one must find some discount rate to find the value today of £2 million in eight years time. £2 million in seven years time and so on. That is where the 9 per cent figure came in, it being the current rate of interest in a number of loan cases. If one discounts at 9 per cent in order to find the value today of this £16 million one will find that it comes out at something like £10.3 million. So £10.3 million would be the value today of a 2 per cent interest subsidy on a 15-year loan.

The moratorium element has the effect of pushing out the average term of the loan from eight to ten-and-a-half-years, and in this simple example it would have the effect of adding on another £2.7 million to the present day value of the subsidy, so that one would have the interest element of £10.3 million and the subsidy element of £2.7 million, to make a total of £13 million. That means, I trust, that I can now read off in the case of a loan of £225 million, at an interest rate of 9 per cent over a 15-year period that if there is a 3 per cent interest subsidy with no moratorium, the present value of that subsidy is £39,847,000. If there is a five-year moratorium, added on to that subsidy the value increases to £45,565,000 and rounding that off, that is the £45 million to which the Taoiseach referred and indeed which I used in my remarks.

That deals with the first three cases, first, the commercial loan, second, a loan where there is an interest subsidy, and, third, a loan where there is a subsidy and a moratorium. I now need to introduce a further example in order to deal with the alleged contradiction between my remarks on radio and the Taoiseach's statement. I want to introduce the concept of inflation which I trust most of us recognise exists. I trust we would agree that inflation means that £100 next year is not as valuable as £100 this year and its purchasing power is reduced by whatever inflation figure one cares to insert. This problem of inflation will be reflected in the interest rate that would normally apply on commercial loans because, for instance, if one takes a 9 per cent interest rate that would be very high to be a real rate of interest; historically it would be very high because the real rate of interest for long periods of time has been in the region of 3 to 4 per cent and so 9 per cent interest rates reflect the fact people observe inflation to be present and allow for it in the sum of money that they want on any particular loan, because they now want the money to cover both their real earnings and they want money to cover the inflation effect, the fall in the value of their money. The point I was making in my remarks on radio is that if one discounts an interest subsidy and if one takes in the value of a moratorium at a 9 per cent interest one is understating the true value of that moratorium, because if one eliminated the inflation element in the interest rate, that is, if one discounted these future sums of money not by 9 per cent which has an inflation element in it but by, say, 5 per cent if we allow that inflation over the next five or ten years might on average be in the 4 per cent range, that would have the effect of increasing the present value of the subsidy by another 3 or 4 percentage points. That was the point I was making on radio. That was the basis of the remarks I made that it also had a value but I had not yet placed a figure on it. The reason I have not yet placed a figure on it, I hope will be recognised from the simple example I have given, which shows that it can be fairly complex trying to take account of the impact of inflation rates on prospective future sums of money.

Speaker.P: It was obviously too complex for Deputy FitzGerald.
There is another economist here and I am sure he will tell all this to him in great detail.
I can understand why the Taoiseach did not reply.
I was invited to give this lecture. I promised to give it and I am giving it. I hope the Deputies can take it because they have been shaping up for this for a long time.
(Interruptions).
Deputy Kelly said he welcomed interruptions and I welcome them too.
Deputy Kelly said we wasted our time.

That was why I said we had not yet placed a value on it. I want to make it clear that it is even more complex than that because if one allows for variations in the rate of inflation during the 15-year period this affects the nature of the calculation one makes. I also want to say that if the Deputies think that the rate of inflation is not adequately accounted for in interest rates——
(Interruptions.)

I will use my time as I think appropriate just the same way as Deputy FitzGerald did, sneeringly and undermining the position of the Taoiseach, alleging that there was discontent and disputes between the Taoiseach and his Ministers. This is my first occasion to refute every one of those allegations and to show that all the error and confusion stems from the far side of the House. The final point I want to make on this brings me back to my earlier remarks. If one allows for the presence of inflation, which is contained in all of the current interest rates, then a moratorium, even on a commercial loan, may have a value. I would like to know, therefore, what question Deputy FitzGerald put to his five alleged experts before I know if the answer they gave was correct or not.

At the outset I specified a case with no inflation and I said in those circumstances it would have no value. I suggested that most present interest rates include an inflation element. I would like to know what question was put and what answer was given. I have demonstrated for Deputy FitzGerald's benefit that a moratorium has a value. I have demonstrated the way in which one calculates the value of the moratorium in interest subsidy. I have demonstrated that if he could not understand the statement made by the Taoiseach that the failing was on his part not on ours. Incidentally, for an alleged economic expert, I could not believe it when he said he did not understand a simple economic statement like the present value of something discounted at 9 per cent.
(Interruptions.)
Deputy Kelly had his chance and I hope he spoke without interruptions. I would like the Minister to conclude in the same manner.

I finally demonstrated that my remarks on radio last week in no way contradicted anything that had been said by the Taoiseach. I have now dealt with that point fully and fairly. I was entitled to do that.
(Interruptions.)
That shows why the Deputy is on that side of the House. I will send him a few good text books.
(Interruptions.)
Would Deputy Collins allow the Minister to continue?
What did the editor of The Irish Times say?

Are Fine Gael stuck for another economic expert? I would like to deal with a number of the other points that were raised but time presses on. I want to say something about the terms in order to clarify the matter, particularly in relation to Deputy Cluskey's remarks. First of all, if we distinguish that what has been proposed in the EMS context is a package of loans on the one hand accompanied by a subsidy which can be converted into a cash payment it represents a grant. Let us separate the two elements and now let us see——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: The Government are only getting loans.
I ask Deputy Collins to stop interrupting.

There are two elements on offer. One is loans at a normal rate of interest. If we separate the subsidy and take that as a cash grant it becomes a cash transfer. I would have hoped, after the examples I have given, that there was no need to debate that any further.
(Interruptions.)

The Deputy should go back to first-year studies. said let us take the grant and let us take the loan at the normal commercial rate Deputy Horgan implied that if we availed of these loans this would double our level of indebtedness and that it would in some sense undermine our bedgetary strategy and so forth. Deputy Bruton also implied that it would have to increase our borrowing figure and would affect our domestic money supply. Let us be clear on this. If we take those loans, they become part of the normal financing of the Government's capital programme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: External.

Yes. If external financing is not required, if the effect of these loans is then simply to add to our foreign reserves there is nothing to prevent us using some of our external reserves to repay some of the existing foreign debt so that at the end of the transaction if one does not need any additional foreign borrowing one does not add to one's foreign debt. One simply offsets this loan by a repayment of existing foreign loans. One's net foreign indebtedness at the end of the period need not be any higher.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: The Minister is not fit for first year.

The Deputy is not fit for first year. He cannot understand that. All of the statements along those lines from the other side of the House are wrong. I am not mincing words and there is no confusion about that. If anybody wants to challenge that statement of mine I invite him to give his own lecture in his own time. The loans do not mean that we are committed to any level of foreign borrowing higher than we would otherwise make. We may or may not need to make some additional foreign borrowing. That is something which must be determined in the circumstances of the time, whether it is next year or any other later year.

MainHeading.P: The loan aspect of it does not affect our position except perhaps positively. If there is any need for foreign borrowing in the coming years is it not comforting to know that that borrowing facility is already available? There do not have to be any rumours, scares or other types of hysterical outbursts to imply that in order to finance the Government's programme there will be a shortage of credit for other investors in the economy. One banishes any speculation of that kind by demonstrating that a loan facility is already available.

We have established that loans can have a positive value. They do not automatically commit us to any increase in our foreign indebtedness. They certainly do not commit us to any additional indebtedness over and above that which de desire. We have also established that the subsidy element represents a real transfer of resources. The question then must remain: “Is that level of grant sufficient?” We have heard a statement from Deputy O'Leary, who told us that the Labour Party will support entry if the terms are right, and Deputy FitzGerald and also Deputy Kelly have implied that Fine Gael would support entry also if the terms were right. We, too, have been saying that we would support entry if the terms are right, but the question is what are the right terms? That is a matter for debate in the context of numbers. I have not time for that now, but I trust that my earlier illustrations were sufficient to show why I do not accept Deputy Kelly's type of calculation. There is a question, then, of other conditions or circumstances. Deputy O'Leary spoke of the importance of safeguarding employment. That consideration has been the prime basis of our approach.

One of the reasons for our saying that any transfer should be concentrated in a form that would enable us to improve our investment, to improve our infrastructure and other facilities was, taking the long-term view, to improve the efficiency of and reduce costs for firms operating in an Irish environment. That is a way in which the competitive position is helped and in which employment is safeguarded. The shorter-term effects are that this would insulate that type of inflow of funds from having any adverse effect on our inflation. We do not want such an adverse effect. If you are accelerating your spending in these infrastructural programmes it is possible to provide more jobs whether in road building, in the supply of telephone services or in other types of infrastructure. Deputy Kelly appeared to be rather sneering about the value of such an approach. All I can say is that if an extra £50 million or so is spent each year in these areas, it must lead to a significant addition of several thousand employed in those areas.

The Deputy raised the question, too, of the possibility of adverse effects on existing industries, but most of the hypothetical circumstances that were referred to were circumstances in which Ireland would become a member while Britain would remain outside with the British £ being devalued against the Irish £ and our firms, therefore, being at a cost disadvantage. But at a cost disadvantage of how much? How can one put a figure on it now? Surely the appropriate position to adopt is to recognise that there are a number of hypothetical situations and to develop——

Speaker.P: That is what the White Paper should have been all about.

——an appropriate kind of policy which could be applied should any of those hypothetical situations arise. That is the approach we will adopt. I assure the House and in particular I want the message to go out to trade union members, to management and to all others concerned, both inside and outside the House, that it is because we are determined to ensure that the EMS of itself will not have any adverse effect on our employment performance or on our ability to generate improvements in our living standards that we have been pursuing the negotiations in the manner in which we have been pursuing them, and we envisage pursuing those approaches until we are satisfied as to the nature of the conditions that would exist in an EMS context. But I must say that it is not only a question of what Europe can do for us. It is also very much a question of what we can do for ourselves.

This morning Deputy FitzGerald quoted some remarks of mine that were published in a magazine when I spoke about offsetting action. The Deputy seemed to be going on to imply that all of that had to come from Europe, and that was why I interrupted him to make clear that some of the offsetting action had to come from within the country. There is no point in any Irish Government, from whatever party or of whatever complexion, going off to Europe and saying that we need certain financial supports as well as other supports in order to maintain some level of performance and to achieve some increase in employment if, when they come back home, the behaviour within the economy is such as to undermine the prospects of achieving those results. That is why the Taoiseach and other Ministers have been saying that in an EMS context there must be a more realistic approach to a number of industrial relations issues and to a number of other related issues, but it is the incomes issue that has been highlighted in the remarks. While we envisage real increases in living standards and in incomes, continuing those increases must be geared to what the economy can afford. It is unrealistic to suggest that real increases in incomes in double figures can occur year after year.
Did Fianna Fáil say that last July 12 months?

Deputy O'Leary spoke of the effects of some of our policies, but may I remind him that he, as Minister, negotiated wage agreements that in themselves would have produced a reduction in the living standard of workers. He said it was our policies this year which led in part to the explosion of wage demands. I suggest that the truth is that after a period of depression, of repression and of various other sorts of recession during which many people were forced to accept reductions in their living standards, there has been a dramatic turnaround in this country's fortunes in the past 18 months.
(Interruptions.)
Order.

Increases are taking place in living standards, and the problem, if there is a problem, is that people are now adjusting to the notion that they can look forward again to genuine improvements taking place. Understandably perhaps, many people are impatient to make good the injustices and the setbacks they had to endure during the four previous wasted years, but those years are now behind us.
Who is the Minister trying to fool?

We say to the people: “yes, we share your ambition. We think it is possible to produce genuine improvements in living standards, but not at an impossible overnight rate”. What we are asking for, whether in an EMS context or in the context of our own circumstances outside the EMS, is a realistic recognition of the pace of improvement which can be sustained, and we are asking also that those who are already fortunate enough to have secure employment will exercise an extra degree of restraint so that we may press ahead with the fastest possible rate of improvement in employment.

MainHeading.P: May I remind Deputy O'Leary, too, that our policies this year have produced the largest single increase in employment in any year since the foundation of the State? That is a fantastic performance, but we should like to see an even better performance next year, and there can be a better performance next year given the right degree of understanding and support. That is the nature of the opportunity that is opening up before the Irish people. It is the nature of the opportunity that may be strengthened and facilitated further within the context of the EMS. It is an opportunity that would give Ireland a chance not only to improve her own circumstances within her own context but to make her contribution, a not unworthy contribution, to the building of that better Europe which is at the heart of the proposals for an EMS. While we may spend our time here debating the precise details of loans, transfers or anything else, it is important to remind ourselves of what this discussion is all about. Ultimately it is all about the possibility of creating a major new element in the construction of a European union, the possibility of a further major step forward along the path to European union. Surely that is an ambition that ought to be shared by many people here on both sides of the House. It is for that reason that we would expect widespread support both inside the House and outside for attempts to bring about, not only the construction of that EMS, but the most effective opportunity for Ireland to participate in such a system.

Speaker.P: Hear, hear.
Question put: “That the words proposed to be deleted stand.”

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Low Rise Mortgage Scheme.

Speaker.P: I presume that I have ten minutes.
The Deputy has ten minutes, and five minutes to the Minister.

I want to raise the question of the administration of the Low Rise Mortgage Scheme and its application to single-parent families where there is only one child. According to Dublin Corporation, the scheme applies to persons who, at least one year prior to the date of application, had applied and been accepted by Dublin Corporation at the time as constituting a family of three persons in need of rehousing on the ground that their existing accommodation was dangerous and so on.

Specifically the issue here is that Dublin Corporation have regarded single parent families, with one child, as being the equivalent of three people and, for their housing purposes, have always regarded that to be the case. Recently an application by a single parent, with one child, for a low rise mortgage scheme was turned down by Dublin Corporation. When I challenged their decision I was told that the Department had ruled specifically—in their interpretation of this—and had clearly indicated that while the corporation may give the loan of the capital sum, the Government were not prepared, in the interpretation of the Department, to pay the subsidy.

I want to ascertain from the Minister who is running the Department of the Environment. First of all, in the Fianna Fáil Manifesto it is said that because Fianna Fáil believe that as many families as possible should own their own homes they will make it easier to buy a house and cheaper to keep it. That is the manifesto promise. The White Paper published in January 1978 at paragraph 5.7 said:
It is the Government's policy to help and encourage as many as possible to provide their own homes.
The Green Paper published in June 1978, at paragraph 5.16 said:

MainHeading.P: The Government's policy is to ensure that as many people as possible are able to purchase their own homes rather than have to rely on rented accommodation. To enable them to do so, there must be an adequate supply of small to medium-sized houses available for purchase at acceptable prices, and there must also be an adequate supply of mortgage finance available in an appropriate form.
The National Economic and Social Council in their comments on the Green Paper, in paragraph 5.15 said:

An important determinant of the demand for housing is the flow of loan finance—especially the flow of building society advances. The flow of advances by building societies is dependent on their net inflow of funds, which in turn is dependent on the flow of deposits.

They go on to say, at paragraph 5.17, that the council agrees with the Green Paper that house purchase should be made easier for some potential house-buyers, in particular for those on relatively low incomes, and then go on to talk about the overall management of funds.

Therefore, in three specific quotations, one before the general election and two afterwards, the indications and policy of this Government are fairly clear. However, its interpretation in the lower regions of the Department does not appear to be so. When this question arose I put a Parliamentary Question to the Minister asking him if he would revise the regulations of the low rise mortgage scheme so that single parents with one child who otherwise meet the requirements of the loan will become eligible to receive the loan. The Minister's reply essentially was that he was reviewing the situation—a favourite refrain of this Government—and that no decision had been made until that review had been completed.

However, it was not the first time the matter had been brought to the Minister's attention. In fact Cherish had written to the Minister a letter, of which I received a copy and of which the Minister was aware I was receiving a copy, drawing his attention to this administrative anomaly. The Minister replied to Cherish on 6 December, acknowledging their letter, but did not give any indication of what was happening.

I think I have established the case fairly clearly. There is a clear Government policy with regard to encouraging home-ownership. The Government have taken a lot of major initiatives in terms of making finance available and so on. A number of families, and specifically one of my constituents, approached me. I advised the woman in question to go for a low rise mortgage loan. She applied to the corporation. Initially the corporation said: “yes, you qualify on all the normal counts”, and then she was turned down. I contacted the principal officer in the Housing Department of the corporation. He took the matter up with the Department. The Department quite clearly stated that the Government would not be prepared to entertain this application because it was in conflict with their interpretation of the scheme. As I understand, that is the factual situation. If I have not presented the case clearly, it was my intention to do so and I will certainly accept any corrections.

I want to know what is happening in the Minister's Department. I want to know did he specifically make that decision. I want to know if the Minister had on his desk, at any stage, a memorandum or note seeking advice on interpretation of this scheme when it was raised and pressed by the major local authority housing agency in the country, namely, Dublin Corporation.

First of all, I want to know did the Minister himself see this application and refuse it. If he did I want to know how he can reconcile that decision with Government policy as stated in the three documents from which I have quoted. If he did not see it—and I can readily understand he cannot see just everything—I want to know who the official is in the corporation who obviously flew in the face of Government policy. I want to know at what level that official dealt with the matter and I want to know what senior official, assuming the Minister did not see it, okayed the position because I presume, when a matter is raised by a principal officer in the housing department of the corporation, it merits at least a second opinion in the Custom House. It seems to me the Minister's officials do not know what Government policy is, which is regrettable to say the least, and are, therefore, in a contradictory position in regard to the administration and implementation of the Minister's own declared objectives for which he has a democratic mandate and which he has quite clearly repeated on a number of occasions. I have given three Government quotations and the Minister himself is on record on more than one occasion quite clearly reiterating the Government's policy of encouraging home ownership.

If it has not been simply—I am seeking parliamentary language—a ministerial mistake or some confusion on the Minister's part, if that is not the case, I want to know has the Minister actually refused this himself and, if so, can he indicate to the House the amount involved in the subsidy and any additional cost that would fall on the Department if they picked up this additional interpretation of the low rise mortgage scheme with specific reference to single parent families.

Finally, I want to say something about the difficulties of single parent families in trying to get houses in a city like Dublin. First of all, because of the nature of our society, single parent families tend invariably to be female parents with one child or children. If a man is left without a partner and has a child people rush to his aid because he presumably cannot cope with a child or children. If a woman is left in similar circumstances the same response is not there and frequently she is left on her own. Her difficulty in getting a mortgage, in getting guarantees for loans or overdraft, in getting a lease signed are innumerably greater because she is female. The difficulties are there. Cases have been well documented and Fianna Fáil Deputies who know their constituencies know that that is the situation. Yet, here we have a situation where either the Minister, who is ultimately responsible, directly intervened and said “No” in this specific instance when the matter was raised or someone in his Department said “No” and, if somebody in his Department said “No”, I want to know what will happen to him and in what way is the policy going to be changed.

In conclusion, I ask the Minister, having brought this matter to light, if he would, independently of any review of the low rise mortgage scheme referred to in his reply to me on 7 December, forthwith make it known to every local authority that single parent families with one child will be eligible under the general terms of the low rise mortgage scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: This motion refers to the maladministration of my Department. There is no maladministration.
On a point of correction, I did not use “maladministration”. I raised the point of administration.

There is no conflict here between Government policy and the Department of the Environment or myself. With regard to the point as to who decided this, I decided, not the officials. It is very important to realise that this scheme was introduced in November 1976 by the then National Coalition Government and the local authorities are responsible for the administration of the scheme.

The three categories are: (a) an existing tenant or tenant-purchaser of a local authority house who surrenders his dwelling to the local authority on receipt of a loan to purchase a private house; (b) families of three or more persons who, at least one year prior to seeking the loan, had applied to and been accepted by a local authority at that time as being in need of rehousing on the grounds that their existing accommodation was dangerous, structurally unfit or seriously overcrowded and that their financial circumstances were such that they could not reasonably be expected to provide proper accommodation from their own resources, and who are still in need of rehousing; and (c) a person who has been allocated tenancy of a new local authority house and who wishes to purchase that house.

MainHeading.P: These were the conditions laid down by the National Coalition Government, not by my predecessor. This went to Government and the Government made this decision. The Government of the law laid down these three conditions for a person who would have to qualify. A loan under the scheme can be 98 per cent of the cost of the house, or £9,000 maximum, whichever is the lower, and as a measure of the importance which I and the Government attach to this scheme a few months ago we raised the amount which would be available from £7,500 to £9,000.

With regard to the specific category to which the Deputy referred, I am aware of the category and the particular case. It is a matter of concern to me that this is the position but under present conditions that person cannot qualify. As I told the Deputy in my reply to a written question, the whole scheme is being reviewed at the moment and, whether that is a favourite word or one the Deputy does not like with regard to the operation of Departments, that is the position. We are in touch with local authorities in order to get a proper report as to how the scheme is functioning before we make the desired or necessary changes and I am sure the Deputy cannot quibble with that. He asked why I took so long to have a look at the scheme. There is a very simple answer to that. This scheme, worthy as it is, and it is a very good scheme and a very attractive scheme, did not get off the ground last year and it did not get off the ground until we were well into this year. Last year the total amount necessary for the scheme in a full year was £1,500,000.
This year it will exceed £6 million. I have made the necessary cash available outside of the estimated amount at the beginning of the year.

Immediately the returns come back from the local authorities, with particular emphasis on Dublin Corporation, the main authority involved in this scheme, changes will be made but those changes will have to be made by the Government since the scheme was introduced by the Government and the conditions were laid down by the Government. It is my intention to make any changes necessary with all possible haste when I have all the data essential in order to approach the Government.

As an indication of how popular the scheme has become, this year there were 645 applicants in category (a), 509 in category (b), the category referred to by the Deputy, and 549 in category (c). They were the figures on 30 September. An urgent review is, therefore, in everybody's interest. There is no delay on my part with regard to this review and changing the conditions. I repeat no official in my Department is in any way in conflict with Government policy with regard to housing.

Speaker.P: How much is the Minister actually saving by excluding this particular category?
I have not got the figures. I have not got the breakdown but I will get the information for the Deputy.
The Dáil adjourned at 10.00 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Thursday, 14 December 1978.

asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if it is proposed to take any steps to avert the threatened disruption of telecommunications services; and if he will make a statement in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Faulkner) Padraig Faulkner
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Faulkner)
Speaker.P: I am aware of reported threats by unofficial groups to disrupt telecommunications services in support of certain staff claims. My Department do not, of course, negotiate with such groups but with the recognised staff organisations concerned. There are settled procedures available for processing the claims involved and my Department are using and will continue to use these procedures to the full. Unofficial action in breach of agreed procedures can only cause inconvenience and hardship to the public and cannot contribute to the settlement of staff claims.

asked the Minister for Finance if he has received a recommendation from Meath County Council in relation to coast erosion on the Gormanston, Laytown, Bettystown and Mornington areas of County Meath; the action it is proposed to take on the matter; and if the county council can be authorised to carry out immediate remedial work where such action is urgently needed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Colley) George Colley

Authorisation by the commissioners is not necessary in the case of a local authority itself undertaking protection works but if interference with foreshore is involved consent of the Minister for Tourism and Transport is required.

asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is aware of the desire of local farmers to develop the entirety of Narraghmore bog, County Kildare for agricultural purposes; and if he will (a) request the Land Commission to facilitate the local farmers in the division of the bog (b) require the farm development service to assist in any necessary drainage of the bog and (c) give details of the response to any representation his Department or the Land Commission have received from local farmers in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Gibbons) James Gibbons
Speaker.P: No representations from local farmers in relation to this property can be traced in my Department. I am not sure what the Deputy has in mind when he refers to the Land Commission facilitating local farmers in the division of the bog, but I can assure him that on receipt of a definite proposal the Land Commission will be glad to consider whether, and how far, they can be of assistance in the matter.
I may add that it is not the practice of the Farm Development Service of my Department to assist the drainage of large expanses of bogland.
I understand that the Forest and Wildlife Service of the Department of Fisheries and Forestry have under consideration the possibility of acquiring some portion of Narraghmore bog.

asked the Minister for Agriculture if, in practice, in all cases the 30-day permitted movement period for brucellosis coincides with that for tuberculosis; and, in the absence of such coincidence, if the period in which animals may, in fact, be moved is less than 30 days.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Gibbons) James Gibbons
Speaker.P: Because of the different nature of the tests for TB and brucellosis the dates of the tests may not always coincide. In the normal course, however, this should not mean that the herd-owner has less than 30 days in which to move his cattle. I appreciate that in some individual cases, the time may be slightly curtailed but it would be extremely difficult to ensure an absolutely uniform period in all cases.

asked the Minister for Agriculture if he is aware of delays of up to three weeks in the punching of reactors; and the average delay from notification to the District Veterinary Office of the existence of the reactor.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Gibbons) James Gibbons
Speaker.P: As I announced some time ago, it is intended that all animals which react to the tuberculin test will be ear-punched at the time of reading the result of the test. Arrangements have been completed for the introduction of this system in January next and it is expected that any delays occurring in the identification of reactors under the present arrangements will then be eliminated.

Speaker.P: Since 1 January 1978, work permits are not necessary in the case of EEC nationals who wish to take up employment in this country.
